case_name: Assistant Collector of Land Customs, Amritsar v. Barkat Ram

facts.text: Barkat Ram was the engine driver of 78 Down Train which reached Amritsar at about 4:15 P.M. on June 8, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Barkat Ram, respondent in this appeal, was the engine driver of 78 Down Train which reached Amritsar at about 4-15 P.m., on June 8, 1957.

facts.text: The train came from Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The train came from Pakistan. In companysequence of information received with respect to the smuggling of gold by the engine crew,

facts.text: Information received with respect to the smuggling of gold by the engine crew.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of information received with respect to the smuggling of gold by the engine crew, the Land Customs staff boarded the engine at Atari

facts.text: Land Customs staff boarded the engine at Atari and other staff surrounded the engine on arrival at Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: the Land Customs staff boarded the engine at Atari and other staff of the Department surrounded the engine on its arrival at Amritsar.

facts.text: A quantity of gold was recovered from underneath the coal in the front part of the coal tender in the engine.

anchor.surface_text: The engine was searched and a quantity of gold was recovered, having been found lying companycealed underneath the companyl in the front part of the companyl tender in the engine.

facts.text: Respondent was interrogated at Customs Station and another quantity of gold recovered from rear part of coal tender.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was further interrogated at the Customs Station and, as a result of further search, another quantity of gold was recovered from the rear part of the companyl tender.

facts.text: Document Ex. P.E. dated June 5, 1957 was recovered.

anchor.surface_text: A document, Ex. P.E., dated June 5, 1957, was also recovered. This document was shown to the respondent on June 9 1957,

facts.text: On June 9, 1957, respondent inscribed on Ex. P.E. that it was the letter given by Tawaqual Shah to deliver to Ghulam Mohd. at Grand Hotel.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent inscribed on this document the numbere Ex. P. D1 to the effect the letter is the same which Tawaqual Shah had given to me yesterday. The same to be delivered to Ghulam Mohd. who has companye from Pakistan and has stayed at Grand Hotel.

facts.text: On June 9, 1957, Barkat Ram made statement Ex. P.K. to Manohar Singh Bedi, Inspector of Customs, admitting smuggling 65 bars of gold.

anchor.surface_text: On June 9, 1957, Barkat Ram, the respondent, made certain other statements, Ex. P. K., to Manohar Singh Bedi, Inspector of Customs, stating therein As usual on the 8th June, 1957, I took two bundles of Indian Currency from Ghulam Mohd. at Amritsar to Pakistan and when I brought 65 bars of gold from Tawakal Shah, from Pakistan, the Customs Officers recovered these 65 bars o gold from the engine at the Railway Station, Amritsar.

facts.text: Gold hidden in presence of firemen Shri Ram Murti and Shri Jagan Nath at Loco Shed, Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: I had kept companycealed these 65 bars of gold in the engine in the presence , of Shri Ram Murti and Shri Jagan Nath, my two Firemen, at the Loco Shed. Lahore. I was to deliver this gold to Ghulam Mohd. at Amritsar.

facts.text: Second statement Ex. P.G. made on June 17, 1957 to same Inspector, adding Rs. 200 reward.

anchor.surface_text: A second statement was made to the same Customs Inspector on June 17, 1957, Ex. P. G. On this occasion too, he made a similar statement, adding that he was to get Rs. 200 against the delivery of gold.

facts.text: Complaint filed by Assistant Collector of Land Customs, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: On the companyplaint of the Assistant Collector of Land Customs, Amritsar, Barkat Ram tried for offences punishable under s. 23  1  of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947,

facts.text: Barkat Ram convicted by Magistrate under s.23(1) Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947 and s.167(81) Sea Customs Act 1878 as amended 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and under s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act, 1978, as amended in 1955. He was companyvicted by the Magistrate.

facts.text: Conviction confirmed by appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction was companyfirmed by the appellate Court, but was set aside on revision by the High Court

facts.text: Punjab High Court set aside conviction on October 9, 1958 in Criminal Revision No. 599 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 9, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 599 of 1958.

facts.text: High Court held Customs Officers are police officers under s.25 Evidence Act, statements inadmissible, no other evidence.

anchor.surface_text: which held that Customs Officers were police officers within the meaning of that expression in s. 25 of the Evidence Act, that companyfessional statements made to them were companysequently inadmissible in evidence and that if they be excluded from companysideration, there was numberother evidence to sustain the companyviction.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal: Criminal Appeal No. 45 of 1959 by special leave by State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 45 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 9, 1958,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Customs Officers not police officers under s.25 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the companytention for the appellant is sound and that the Customs Officers are number police officers within the meaning of that term in s. 25 of the Evidence Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside acquittal, restores conviction.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of acquittal of the respondent for the aforesaid offences and restore the order of companyviction passed by the Magistrate and companyfirmed by the Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Subba Rao J. dissents, holds Customs officers are police officers qua police functions.

anchor.surface_text: SUBBA RAO J.-I regret my inability to agree. ... I, therefore hold that a Customs officer is a police officer qua his police functions.

facts.text: Appeal heard on August 30, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 30. The judgment of J. L. Kapur and Raghubar Dayal, JJ. was delivered by Raghubar Dayal, J.

holdings.text: the Customs Officers are not police officers within the meaning of that term in s. 25 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the contention for the appellant is sound and that the Customs Officers are not police officers within the meaning of that term in s. 25 of the Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers conferred on Customs Officers under Sea Customs Act and Land Customs Act are for levy of duties, prevention of smuggling, and revenue protection, distinct from police duties of crime prevention and detection under Police Act 1861

holdings.text: the Customs Officers are not police officers for the purpose of s. 25 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Customs Officers are not police officers for the purpose of s. 25 of the Evidence Act. We further hold that the conviction of the respondent for the offences under s. 23 1  of the Foreign

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry under s.171A Sea Customs Act is judicial proceeding; Customs Officers act judicially; Act distinguishes police officers from Customs Officers; object of s.25 limited to police malpractices

holdings.text: the conviction of the respondent for the offences under s. 23(1) of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, and under s.167(81) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, on the basis of his statements to the Customs Officers, was legal and was wrongly set aside by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: We further hold that the conviction of the respondent for the offences under s. 23 1  of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, and under s.167 81  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, as amended in 1955, on the basis of his statements

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statements admissible as Customs Officers not police officers under s.25 Evidence Act; High Court erred in excluding them and acquitting for lack of other evidence

holdings.text: allow the appeal, set aside the order of acquittal of the respondent for the aforesaid offences and restore the order of conviction passed by the Magistrate and confirmed by the Sessions Judge
